qualitative_analysis.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
qualitative_analysis.quote: Revenue sources for SaaS are different from those of on-premise software in that the 'perpetual' usage license fee is no longer applicable and clients are charged for only what they have utilized, usually on a periodic basis.
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes the incompatibility between perpetual licensing and SaaS models, requiring transformation to usage-based pricing and new revenue streams.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
qualitative_analysis.quote: given the nature of SaaS as remotely hosted software services, switching is neither expensive nor tedious for clients
qualitative_analysis.justification: Directly describes low switching costs as a characteristic restriction of the SaaS business model that creates retention pressure.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
qualitative_analysis.quote: SaaS is single versioned, meaning that there is only one version of software being accessed by every client at any moment in time
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes the technical architecture restriction where SaaS cannot maintain multiple software versions for different clients.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
qualitative_analysis.quote: adopting more components in software pricing will result in complicated pricing solutions, which are often translated to high overheads at the vendors' side, such as extra cost for customer care support
qualitative_analysis.justification: Identifies the trade-off and restriction that complex pricing increases operational overhead costs, limiting pricing flexibility.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Selection of the Proper Revenue and Pricing Model for SaaS
qualitative_analysis.quote: However, not all customers are willing to rent the software through the public cloud, due to security concerns or a low readiness for new technologies.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Selection of the Proper Revenue and Pricing Model for SaaS
qualitative_analysis.quote: some customers had an IT policy that did not allow installation of any software outside their own internal data center
qualitative_analysis.justification: IT policies restrict cloud-based remote hosting models, forcing on-premises alternatives and limiting SaaS adoption.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Selection of the Proper Revenue and Pricing Model for SaaS
qualitative_analysis.quote: Another reason to sell a traditional license for internal use was a lack of network connections, in certain cases where a customer was in the process of building a new telecom network
qualitative_analysis.justification: Highlights the fundamental incompatibility where SaaS requires internet connectivity, creating barriers in certain deployment scenarios.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
qualitative_analysis.quote: the KPIs (key performance indicator) at the same were based on the sales of on-premise products, and rendered as a conflict to the transition to cloud.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
qualitative_analysis.quote: a key question that has risen in every partner's mind is "...given there is nothing to resell, nothing to technically install and no opportunity to provide any kind of logistics, what can a successful SaaS partner contribute?"

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
qualitative_analysis.quote: Financially, this renders as a challenge, as such delivery model is considered to have significantly decreased switching costs for customers.
qualitative_analysis.justification: Subscription delivery model reduces switching costs compared to perpetual licenses, making customer retention harder.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Managing a Software Business
qualitative_analysis.quote: Many other things determine your offering's quality: its usability, security, maintainability, reliability, and efficiency. All these elements are at odds with each other, and all drive up costs.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Managing a Software Business
qualitative_analysis.quote: Existing revenue streams might dry up before new ones start bringing in cash

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Towards a better Understanding of the Dynamics of Platform as a Service Business Models
qualitative_analysis.quote: Another revenue stream which seems to be present within the PaaS ecosystem is open source software. Even though this revenue stream is mainly non-monetary
qualitative_analysis.justification: Open source in PaaS platforms restricts direct monetary revenue generation, requiring alternative monetization strategies.
